blog.description: I am Rai, a 28-year-old, short, queer motherfucker. They/Them.

title: Funny Lingering Soul Molly thought
body:
They are affected by things specified for undead creatures, such as Turn Undead.

Someone casts Turn Undead, Molly shrieks and runs away. Everyone’s like “Molly wait come back!” They watch him run into the distance…. and then he hits his 150ft distance limit from who/whatever he’s bound to and reacts like a dog hitting the end of its chain, feet fly out from under him and lands flat on his ghostly back.

reblog.comment:

summary: Hey quick question! I love Taz and really wanna get into Critical Role so I was wodering where do I watch/listen to it? Thanks!!
question: Hey quick question! I love Taz and really wanna get into Critical Role so I was wodering where do I watch/listen to it? Thanks!!
answer: Hiya! You can watch it on the Geek & Sundry YouTube and Twitch pages. You can also download it as a podcast, and it’s also on VRV. If you google Critical Role, it’ll pop up.

reblog.comment: Hiya! You can watch it on the Geek & Sundry YouTube and Twitch pages. You can also download it as a podcast, and it’s also on VRV. If you google Critical Role, it’ll pop up.

tags: you are not allowed to die damn it
summary: I am seriously considering taking a break from this campaign until we know Molly's final fate.  I can then do a catch up...
body:
I am seriously considering taking a break from this campaign until we know Molly’s final fate. I can then do a catch up weekend. And, hopefully not have a breakdown because yeah.

Maybe I will continue catching up with Campaign 1? At least there I am secure in my knowledge that none of them permanently die. (Well, maybe Vax? I am not quite sure how the Raven Queen stuff works. But that was towards the end I think.)

title: Worried
body:
The more I think about it, the more worried I am that we have two options:

1) Taliesin wants to bring Molly back, the team finds a way to make it happen.

2) Taliesin doesn’t want to bring Molly back and rolls up a new character, not a Blood Hunter.

What I really want is a third option:

3) Taliesin and Matt work out some weird thing where Molly can come back but with a different class.

Taliesin hasn’t seemed very happy playing Blood Hunter. The team desperately needs a support healer. It’s early yet in the campaign. Molly just died in a place with no easy access to a healer capable of bringing him back. If Taliesin wanted to switch to a new character … now is the time. And if it’s going to happen, it’d be better to do it now, with so much of the campaign ahead of us.

I hope I’m wrong. I really hope I’m wrong. All weekend I’ve seen people devastated about Molly’s death. A lot of fans, and a lot of new fans, really identified with him. If he stays dead this will hit people real hard and I don’t wanna see that happen. The world is a bleak and difficult place right now; nobody needs more sadness in their life.

summary: Science Teacher D&D: Terminal Velocity, Creature Size, and Polymorph
title: Science Teacher D&D: Terminal Velocity, Creature Size, and Polymorph
body:
AKA why yes, Matt Mercer was correct to kill Keyleth when she jumped off a cliff and turned into a goldfish, but turning into a goldfish is still a pretty viable strategy for surviving that, not because it’s a fish but because it’s tiny.

[for screen readers: video is an animation set to an audio clip from Critical Role. The druid Keyleth jumps incautiously off a cliff over the ocean and realizes she is falling towards the slope of the cliff face. She uses Gust to push herself out but is still heading towards the rocks at the foot of the cliff. She turns herself into a goldfish, hits the rock, takes 360 points of fall damage, and is insta-killed]

OK, so, there are a few things going on here. I do actually think Matt made the correct call here according to physics, biology, and the rules of 5th Edition. However…. there are lots of cases where I think the 5e rules handle fall damage poorly, and size Tiny creatures absolutely fall into that category. There was a way for Keyleth to use the goldfish beast shape here that would have accomplished what she was trying to do.

Topics Explored Below Cut:

1. Let’s talk about what terminal velocity is
2. Size tiny creatures have low terminal velocity and a high surface area to volume ratio
3. Tiny creatures can survive falls from remarkable heights
3a. If Keyleth had been a goldfish the whole time she was falling (rather than turning into one at the end) she probably would have survived.
4. Rule suggestions: You could try incrementing the damage dice for fall damage based on the size OR it might be easier to just exempt tiny creatures from fall damage and insta-KO huge and larger ones (wings make it fiddly though)

OK, let’s unpack that

First of all, this video does a great job of explaining the concepts I’m going to get into. It’s probably more helpful than reading this explanation, and you should totally check it out. In short, an animal’s size makes a huge difference in how well it survives a fall because of two things:

1. terminal velocity

2. surface area to volume ratio

1. Terminal velocity will be familiar to people who have seen my post about fall distance.  When you start to fall, gravity makes you accelerate, falling faster and faster over time.  As your speed/velocity increases, the air pushes back against you (just like when you put your hand out a car window, you feel more “wind” the faster the car is moving). At a certain point (different for every creature or object) that push, known as “air friction” or “drag,” is enough to equal the pull of gravity and you stop accelerating and hit a steady downward speed, known as your terminal velocity. (FYI: if you are a typical human being in that skydiver jumping jack position, your body’s terminal velocity is probably around 120 mph)

Objects with a high weight and a small surface area (like smooth rocks, or cannonballs) have high terminal velocities. Objects with low weights and large surface areas, like balloons or bedsheets, have low terminal velocities. Their “top speed” is much slower. In general, the larger an animal is, the faster its terminal velocity will be. An ant falls much more slowly than a mouse, which falls more slowly than a human, which falls more slowly than a whale.  An ant will hit the ground much more gently than a human will.

[sidenote: “terminal” doesn’t mean “deadly” in this case. While terminal velocity for some species can be fatal, that’s not necessarily the case for all and it’s not why it’s called that. It’s “terminal” in the sense of being the final speed you always eventually reach if you fall long enough]

2. Surface area to volume ratio is a little harder to explain. Basically, it describes how much outside you have compared to your inside. Think of it like making a cake where you keep doubling the recipe; if you triple the amount of batter (the volume of the inside) the amount of icing you need to cover the outside (the surface area) might only be double what you needed for the original cake. Also, your cake might taste too cake-y and not enough icing-y because the ratio is messed up and there’s too much cake that’s way too far from any delicious icing.
[Skippable Math Justification: remember that the equation for the volume of a shape usually has the radius cubed, but the surface area for the same shape will have the radius squared.  The bigger an object or creature gets, the less outside it has compared to the amount of inside if it keeps the same shape.]

Surface area to volume ratio is important in biology for lots of reasons (two big ones are how much heat you retain and how easily you can get nutrients into your body), but one really important one is how sturdy and tough a creature is. In general, smaller creatures have more support compared to the amount of weight/inside volume/squishy stuff they have, and that makes them tougher against gravity and crushing pressure. Think about how difficult it is to crush a flea with a magazine compared to how easily the much larger housefly squishes. This is also why whales can get so big in the ocean but die on land; their size is so great that they are pretty vulnerable to their own weight.

Why You Should Care
Okay, so what does this have to do with Keyleth?  Well, for many real-world tiny creatures, their slow terminal velocity combined with their great toughness for their weight means that they literally can’t be dropped from high enough to kill them. You could drop an ant off a cliff and it would not hit the ground hard enough to really care. I got interested in this topic last year and went looking for information on how different species perform when falling from great heights (Sidenote: be careful googling this if animal cruelty upsets you; people suck).

Rough breakdown of IRL fall damage from great heights:
Most insects: fine with basically whatever.
Mouse: soft surface usually fine, hard surface 50-50. 
Smaller fish: fine into water, sometimes die if they hit land. 
Rat or ferret: 50-50 on soft surface, usually die on hard one.
Cats: sometimes die but survive very high falls more often than shorter ones
Anything bigger than a cat: going to die more often than not
Humans: mostly die from terminal velocity falls, but a few of us have made it
Horse or elephant: is never going to survive that.

Back to Keyleth
So, Keyleth picked a form (goldfish) that had a pretty good chance of surviving a fall from a great height. Obviously aiming for the water would have been better. However, even on the rocks she might have stood a chance because her terminal velocity would have been so much lower and her surface-area-to-volume ratio would have been pretty good.  Her fatal error: she waited until the last minute to shift forms, meaning that she was traveling at full human terminal velocity when she struck down on rock. This is not a case of dropping a goldfish off a cliff; in the real world you would have to fire a goldfish out of a cannon to get that speed downward. So, Mercer was correct in this case, but I stand by the assessment that the rules aren’t written in a way that accommodates terminal velocity.

Heavy-duty Most Accurate Rules I Don’t Really Recommend:
Tiny creatures are exempt from fall damage altogether if they were tiny for the duration of the fall
Small creatures take d4s (note that this includes gnomes and halflings)
Medium creatures take d6s
Large creatures take d10s
Huge or larger creatures go unconscious with 0 HP immediately if they free fall more than 20 feet.
(caveat: something like a Roc that flies with wings is only going to truly free fall if it’s unconscious or its wings have been removed; even if its wings are damaged it’s going to attempt to use them to slow down rather than face certain death. Use normal fall damage if they’re conscious and their wings are still attached to their body) 
(I wouldn’t actually use these, but they’re more accurate)

Quick and Dirty Rules: Give fall damage as normal EXCEPT:
Tiny creatures take no fall damage,
Huge or larger creatures go unconscious with 0 HP immediately if they free-fall from more than 20 feet. For winged creatures apply normal fall damage unless wings are removed or creature is paralyzed.

Practical Upshot: If my druid beast-shaped to an ant or a spider and leapt off a cliff I wouldn’t make them take damage. If the rogue used his scroll of mass polymorph to turn them all into spiders I would let them all make the jump safely. If Keyleth had turned into a goldfish at the start of her fall I would probably have let her live, although she might have been stunned for a little bit by the rocks.

Mouse: soft surface usually fine, hard surface 50-50. 
Smaller fish: fine into water, sometimes die if they hit land. 
Rat or ferret: 50-50 on soft surface, usually die on hard one.
Cats: sometimes die but survive very high falls more often than shorter ones
Anything bigger than a cat: going to die more often than not
Humans: mostly die from terminal velocity falls, but a few of us have made it
Horse or elephant: is never going to survive that.

Back to Keyleth
So, Keyleth picked a form (goldfish) that had a pretty good chance of surviving a fall from a great height. Obviously aiming for the water would have been better. However, even on the rocks she might have stood a chance because her terminal velocity would have been so much lower and her surface-area-to-volume ratio would have been pretty good.  Her fatal error: she waited until the last minute to shift forms, meaning that she was traveling at full human terminal velocity when she struck down on rock. This is not a case of dropping a goldfish off a cliff; in the real world you would have to fire a goldfish out of a cannon to get that speed downward. So, Mercer was correct in this case, but I stand by the assessment that the rules aren’t written in a way that accommodates terminal velocity.

Heavy-duty Most Accurate Rules I Don’t Really Recommend:
Tiny creatures are exempt from fall damage altogether if they were tiny for the duration of the fall
Small creatures take d4s (note that this includes gnomes and halflings)
Medium creatures take d6s
Large creatures take d10s
Huge or larger creatures go unconscious with 0 HP immediately if they free fall more than 20 feet.
(caveat: something like a Roc that flies with wings is only going to truly free fall if it’s unconscious or its wings have been removed; even if its wings are damaged it’s going to attempt to use them to slow down rather than face certain death. Use normal fall damage if they’re conscious and their wings are still attached to their body) 
(I wouldn’t actually use these, but they’re more accurate)

Quick and Dirty Rules: Give fall damage as normal EXCEPT:
Tiny creatures take no fall damage,
Huge or larger creatures go unconscious with 0 HP immediately if they free-fall from more than 20 feet. For winged creatures apply normal fall damage unless wings are removed or creature is paralyzed.

Practical Upshot: If my druid beast-shaped to an ant or a spider and leapt off a cliff I wouldn’t make them take damage. If the rogue used his scroll of mass polymorph to turn them all into spiders I would let them all make the jump safely. If Keyleth had turned into a goldfish at the start of her fall I would probably have let her live, although she might have been stunned for a little bit by the rocks.

trail.content_raw:
AKA why yes, Matt Mercer was correct to kill Keyleth when she jumped off a cliff and turned into a goldfish, but turning into a goldfish is still a pretty viable strategy for surviving that, not because it’s a fish but because it’s tiny.

[for screen readers: video is an animation set to an audio clip from Critical Role. The druid Keyleth jumps incautiously off a cliff over the ocean and realizes she is falling towards the slope of the cliff face. She uses Gust to push herself out but is still heading towards the rocks at the foot of the cliff. She turns herself into a goldfish, hits the rock, takes 360 points of fall damage, and is insta-killed]

OK, so, there are a few things going on here. I do actually think Matt made the correct call here according to physics, biology, and the rules of 5th Edition. However…. there are lots of cases where I think the 5e rules handle fall damage poorly, and size Tiny creatures absolutely fall into that category. There was a way for Keyleth to use the goldfish beast shape here that would have accomplished what she was trying to do.

Topics Explored Below Cut:

1. Let’s talk about what terminal velocity is
2. Size tiny creatures have low terminal velocity and a high surface area to volume ratio
3. Tiny creatures can survive falls from remarkable heights
3a. If Keyleth had been a goldfish the whole time she was falling (rather than turning into one at the end) she probably would have survived.
4. Rule suggestions: You could try incrementing the damage dice for fall damage based on the size OR it might be easier to just exempt tiny creatures from fall damage and insta-KO huge and larger ones (wings make it fiddly though)

[[MORE]]

OK, let’s unpack that

First of all, this video does a great job of explaining the concepts I’m going to get into. It’s probably more helpful than reading this explanation, and you should totally check it out. In short, an animal’s size makes a huge difference in how well it survives a fall because of two things:

1. terminal velocity

2. surface area to volume ratio

1. Terminal velocity will be familiar to people who have seen my post about fall distance.  When you start to fall, gravity makes you accelerate, falling faster and faster over time.  As your speed/velocity increases, the air pushes back against you (just like when you put your hand out a car window, you feel more “wind” the faster the car is moving). At a certain point (different for every creature or object) that push, known as “air friction” or “drag,” is enough to equal the pull of gravity and you stop accelerating and hit a steady downward speed, known as your terminal velocity. (FYI: if you are a typical human being in that skydiver jumping jack position, your body’s terminal velocity is probably around 120 mph)

Objects with a high weight and a small surface area (like smooth rocks, or cannonballs) have high terminal velocities. Objects with low weights and large surface areas, like balloons or bedsheets, have low terminal velocities. Their “top speed” is much slower. In general, the larger an animal is, the faster its terminal velocity will be. An ant falls much more slowly than a mouse, which falls more slowly than a human, which falls more slowly than a whale.  An ant will hit the ground much more gently than a human will.

[sidenote: “terminal” doesn’t mean “deadly” in this case. While terminal velocity for some species can be fatal, that’s not necessarily the case for all and it’s not why it’s called that. It’s “terminal” in the sense of being the final speed you always eventually reach if you fall long enough]

2. Surface area to volume ratio is a little harder to explain. Basically, it describes how much outside you have compared to your inside. Think of it like making a cake where you keep doubling the recipe; if you triple the amount of batter (the volume of the inside) the amount of icing you need to cover the outside (the surface area) might only be double what you needed for the original cake. Also, your cake might taste too cake-y and not enough icing-y because the ratio is messed up and there’s too much cake that’s way too far from any delicious icing.
[Skippable Math Justification: remember that the equation for the volume of a shape usually has the radius cubed, but the surface area for the same shape will have the radius squared.  The bigger an object or creature gets, the less outside it has compared to the amount of inside if it keeps the same shape.]

Surface area to volume ratio is important in biology for lots of reasons (two big ones are how much heat you retain and how easily you can get nutrients into your body), but one really important one is how sturdy and tough a creature is. In general, smaller creatures have more support compared to the amount of weight/inside volume/squishy stuff they have, and that makes them tougher against gravity and crushing pressure. Think about how difficult it is to crush a flea with a magazine compared to how easily the much larger housefly squishes. This is also why whales can get so big in the ocean but die on land; their size is so great that they are pretty vulnerable to their own weight.

Why You Should Care
Okay, so what does this have to do with Keyleth?  Well, for many real-world tiny creatures, their slow terminal velocity combined with their great toughness for their weight means that they literally can’t be dropped from high enough to kill them. You could drop an ant off a cliff and it would not hit the ground hard enough to really care. I got interested in this topic last year and went looking for information on how different species perform when falling from great heights (Sidenote: be careful googling this if animal cruelty upsets you; people suck).

Rough breakdown of IRL fall damage from great heights:
Most insects: fine with basically whatever.
Mouse: soft surface usually fine, hard surface 50-50. 
Smaller fish: fine into water, sometimes die if they hit land. 
Rat or ferret: 50-50 on soft surface, usually die on hard one.
Cats: sometimes die but survive very high falls more often than shorter ones
Anything bigger than a cat: going to die more often than not
Humans: mostly die from terminal velocity falls, but a few of us have made it
Horse or elephant: is never going to survive that.

Back to Keyleth
So, Keyleth picked a form (goldfish) that had a pretty good chance of surviving a fall from a great height. Obviously aiming for the water would have been better. However, even on the rocks she might have stood a chance because her terminal velocity would have been so much lower and her surface-area-to-volume ratio would have been pretty good.  Her fatal error: she waited until the last minute to shift forms, meaning that she was traveling at full human terminal velocity when she struck down on rock. This is not a case of dropping a goldfish off a cliff; in the real world you would have to fire a goldfish out of a cannon to get that speed downward. So, Mercer was correct in this case, but I stand by the assessment that the rules aren’t written in a way that accommodates terminal velocity.

Heavy-duty Most Accurate Rules I Don’t Really Recommend:
Tiny creatures are exempt from fall damage altogether if they were tiny for the duration of the fall
Small creatures take d4s (note that this includes gnomes and halflings)
Medium creatures take d6s
Large creatures take d10s
Huge or larger creatures go unconscious with 0 HP immediately if they free fall more than 20 feet.
(caveat: something like a Roc that flies with wings is only going to truly free fall if it’s unconscious or its wings have been removed; even if its wings are damaged it’s going to attempt to use them to slow down rather than face certain death. Use normal fall damage if they’re conscious and their wings are still attached to their body) 
(I wouldn’t actually use these, but they’re more accurate)

Quick and Dirty Rules: Give fall damage as normal EXCEPT:
Tiny creatures take no fall damage,
Huge or larger creatures go unconscious with 0 HP immediately if they free-fall from more than 20 feet. For winged creatures apply normal fall damage unless wings are removed or creature is paralyzed.

Practical Upshot: If my druid beast-shaped to an ant or a spider and leapt off a cliff I wouldn’t make them take damage. If the rogue used his scroll of mass polymorph to turn them all into spiders I would let them all make the jump safely. If Keyleth had turned into a goldfish at the start of her fall I would probably have let her live, although she might have been stunned for a little bit by the rocks.
trail.content:
AKA why yes, Matt Mercer was correct to kill Keyleth when she jumped off a cliff and turned into a goldfish, but turning into a goldfish is still a pretty viable strategy for surviving that, not because it’s a fish but because it’s tiny.

blog.name: nilim
blog.title: The sky may be falling, but the stars look good on you
blog.description:
D&D, Critical Role, Discworld. 
-
I create meta, gifsets, fanart and fanfiction.

My inbox is always open for prompts, and I love getting them... but no guarantees.

summary: So I’ve seen a lot of worry and grief and bargaining in the tags after the last episode, which is completely understandable. We...
body:
So I’ve seen a lot of worry and grief and bargaining in the tags after the last episode, which is completely understandable. We might lose a beloved character, and that always hurts. Trying to bolster each other’s moods with encouraging posts is admirable. 

What I don’t really like is when people spread this sentiment that we shouldn’t worry, because we should simply ‘trust Matt’ and trust the fact he would never let ‘such an important character’ die. 

It implies that in the situation where Molly won’t be successfully resurrected, it will mostly be Matt’s fault, and that whether Molly lives or dies is entirely up to his discretion. 

Barring any radical plot interventions (which to be fair is always a possibility, especially when looking at Molly’s back story), any other day within the Critical Role universe a player character’s death is outside of Matt’s control. It is up to that character’s player and how they RP their wishes to be resurrected, the other players’ ingenuity and the method through which they will try to resurrect the dead character, and most importantly, the roll of a die. 

Matt has carefully built this world and the rules it operates under. He awards players’ originality and ingenuity, and if the others somehow come up with a bloody good plan to help Molly he will most certainly grand them the chance at resurrecting him, but I don’t see Matt bending or breaking the rules if the dice simply don’t roll in Molly’s favour. 

I’ll be delighted if they can resurrect Molly, or if Matt already has a quest ready to find Molly’s soul, or if this was all somehow all part of a larger plan. That would be amazing!

But… if things simply don’t work out in Molly’s favour, and the players are fine with that, I don’t want to see Matt somehow getting the blame for ‘allowing Molly to die’. It’s D&D. It’s a game of chance. And I’m glad it is, it allows for this incredible emergent story-telling; completely separate from what the DM had planned or the players had planned, fates decided by the roll of a die. And it’s that aspect that makes it that these stories are somehow so much more than just the sum of its parts. It’s not ‘lazy writing’, or the DM being evil, and if I see any hate of that kind directed towards Matt because of it I’m going to have some words with you all.

blog.name: shinestoryteller
blog.title: Go and Catch a Falling Star
blog.description:
When everything seems hopeless,
Just take one day at a time.
And if one day is too much,
Just take one hour at a time.
And if one hour is too much,
Just take one minute at a time.

body:
A New Car (err…Blog)!

Hey all!

So, you may have noticed as of late (and by “as of late,” I mean “over the course of the past year”) that there’s been a serious uptick in D&D-related content on this blog. I got into The Adventure Zone last summer, started Critical Role when I finished that, and actually started playing a couple of months ago. All of this is to say, I feel that there is enough material here to warrant its own side blog, so that is precisely what I’m doing.

If you followed me for - or are interested in - content related to TAZ, CR, and other things loosely affiliated with D&D, you can now find sort of stuff over at @peregrinefalchion . I’m going to try to keep some sort of a tag system (we’ll see how long that lasts), and I will generally try to give a 48-hour catch-up window before posting plot-related material (I will, of course, tag spoilers).

This blog will continue to serve as your one-stop shop for adorable animals, vibrant landscape photography, bad jokes, and gifs of the comedies of Michael Schur. Thank you for your time. That is all.

summary:
I'm heartbroken & there is nothing else to say. 

  Mollymauk is my favourite next to Caleb and this was very heavy. I am still...
caption:
I’m heartbroken & there is nothing else to say.

Mollymauk is my favourite next to Caleb and this was very heavy. I am still hopeful in a way but even if it stays like it is, its alright and I respect it. He is special though and I want to see him enjoy life some more…

_______________

Mollymauk from Critical Role
